ygData.subject: Re: Combining NSGA-II and NEAT speciated fitness sharing
ygData.msgSnippet: Hi Oliver, The best way to combine NEAT with NSGA-II (or multiobjective optimization in general) is an open question, but there have been a few precedents that

Subject: Re: Combining NSGA-II and NEAT speciated fitness sharing

Hi Oliver, 

The best way to combine NEAT with NSGA-II (or multiobjective=
 optimization in general) is an open question, but there have been a few pr=
ecedents that seemed to work.  Given the utility of having multiple objecti=
ves, it is indeed an important question.  It's true that the main problem i=
s that it is not clear how speciation should interact with the non-dominate=
d fronts.  

Our group recently has tried simply replacing NEAT-style speci=
ation with a "genetic diversity objective."  The benefit of that approach i=
s that you don't have to worry about the interaction between speciation and=
 the pareto front while you still get some protection for genetic diversity=
; the downside of course is it's not certain that the dynamics will be exac=
tly like fitness sharing.  But you can see an example of this approach in t=
his paper:

http://eplex.cs.ucf.edu/papers/lehman_ab13.pdf

The genetic div=
ersity objective is defined there as: "In particular, the genomic diversity=
 of a given genome is quantifi=0Ced as the average distance to its k-neares=
t neighbors in genotype space as measured by NEAT's genomic distance measur=
e."

Of course, the approach you are suggesting is different and would pres=
erve fitness sharing.  I actually was co-author on a paper that tried to do=
 something like that a while ago, and you can see it here:

http://www.scie=
ncedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0952197610001442

In this paper (if I ca=
n remember correctly) I believe the pareto-ranking is computed within each =
NEAT species and a single fitness score (that can then be modified by fitne=
ss sharing) is assigned to each individual based on pareto-rank. 

I think =
that differs a bit from the options you are considering, but at least it pr=
ovides some context and seemed also to work okay.  I need to think more on =
what is actually the best way to combine these methods because right now I'=
m not sure what is really best, but it seems there are multiple ways you co=
uld go that are at least viable.  The main thing is to make sure that no ma=
tter what you do, you don't lose the ability to protect genetic diversity.
=

Joel might have more comment since he's played with the genetic diversity =
objective (the first approach I mentoined) himself.

Best,

ken

--- In nea=
t@yahoogroups.com, Oliver Coleman <oliver.coleman@...> wrote:
>
> Hi all,
>=
 
> I have another implementation kind of question (I was hoping I would
> =
realise the answer once I wrote it out, but that didn't happen!):
> 
> I'm =
implementing the NSGA-II multi-objective EA method in my (Hyper)NEAT
> soft=
ware (https://github.com/OliverColeman/ahni). I'd like to continue
> using =
speciation and fitness sharing (according to species). It seems I
> need to=
 try and merge the NEAT algorithm and the NSGA-II algorithm, which
> comes =
down to something like:
> 
> Evaluate fitness of entire population
> Specia=
te
> Foreach generation
> Create offspring from existing population
> Selec=
t parents (using speciated fitness)
> Reproduce
> Apply mutation operators
=
> Add offspring to population (NOTE: the population size is now temporarily=

> bigger than the desired size)
> Evaluate fitness of entire population (s=
ome fitness values would need to be
> recalculated (eg novelty) but not oth=
ers)
> Speciate
> Rank and sort population by non-dominance *(**separately =
within each
> species? If not then **using original fitness OR shared fitne=
ss as
> determined by speciation?)*
> Cull population by successively remov=
ing lowest ranked sets (within each
> species) until the desired pop size i=
s reached (is slightly more
> complicated than this)
> 
> I'm wondering fir=
st whether it would be best to do the ranking and sorting
> separately with=
in each species, and if not then is it a good idea to use
> speciated fitne=
ss (as determined by NEAT) when ranking and sorting.
> 
> If not ranking an=
d sorting separately within each species, then a reason
> for using speciat=
ed fitness when ranking and sorting is that speciated
> fitness sharing hel=
ps protect innovation and the ranking and sorting
> determines which member=
s of the population (which at this point includes
> the previous population=
 and the new offspring) will remain for the next
> generation. A possible r=
eason against is that it might "skew" the results
> of the ranking and sort=
ing procedure (which is intended to find the "real"
> Pareto fronts/sets). =
Perhaps as long as the elites (according to each
> objective) are maintaine=
d in a species then it doesn't matter much one way
> or the other.
> 
> (No=
te that there are two selection stages being employed: the one to select
> =
parents to produce offspring (which I think should be the same as that for
=
> NEAT: mating within species, etc), and the one to reduce the population,
=
> after adding offspring to it, to the desired population size).
> 
> I hop=
e the above makes sense, let me know if anything is ambiguous, etc.
> Thank=
s in advance for any advice!
> 
> Cheers,
> Oliver
> 
> T: 0421 972 953 | E=
: oliver.coleman@... | W: http://ojcoleman.com
